element.name: Ardgillan III "The Yew Walk" by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)
element.long-description:
Ardgillan is a very well preserved castle near Skerries to the North of Dublin, surrounded by beautiful gardens and set in a great landscape.
A visit to the castle is highly recommended.
The Yew Walk
One surviving feature still intact in the garden is the Yew Walk which lies to the south of the house and is seen as one approaches from the entrance at Blackhills. This was planted in 1800's during the lifetime of Marianne Taylor, wife of Rev. Henry Edward Taylor. It was the favourite walk of Captain Edward Taylour (1863 - 1938). Local folklore has it that a shadowy figure sometimes seen here is the ghost of a member of the Taylour family. From the cache, you will have spectacular views over the grounds and on a clear day you can see the Mourne mountains in the distance.
Getting There
There are two ways to get to this cache: from the main car park at N 53 34.922 W 006 09.645,
or the pedestrain route at the "Ladies Stairs" at N 53 35.473 W 006 09.365.
If you want to visit this cache using public transport, the bus route to take from Dublin City centre is the No. 33 which will drop you off at the "Ladies Stairs" on the road between Balbriggan and Skerries, the pedestrian entrance to the Demesne via a bridge which spans the road and railway line. Alternatively, you can take the 41 from Dublin City Centre to Swords, and then take the 33A (which from Swords on follows the same route as the 33).
Note that access to the grounds is open from 10am to 5pm in the Wintertime, and 10am to 9pm in the summer (June, July and August).
The Windsockers
element.additional-waypoints:
LS1D4R5 - Lady's Stairs
N 53° 35.473 W 006° 09.365
PK1D4R5 - GC1D4R5 Parking
N 53° 34.922 W 006° 09.645

ul.li:
2010-05-25T19:00:00Z : Found it by Trip52
Found our first GeoCoin, loved the view too. Cache a little damp inside - its dry now [:)] Took GeoCoin, Left bouncy ball. TFTC.

2010-05-03T19:00:00Z : Found it by niallk1234
Easy find, first of 4 for today. Looks like I was first to find it for a while. Beautiful day with great views from GZ. Took the travel bug and left a geocoin. Thanks for the cache.

2010-01-16T20:00:00Z : Found it by sandmartin
Found on my jog around Ardgillan. Took Panda and Christmas tree, left Red Squirrel, even though I only ever came across grey squirrels in Ardgillan. TFTC.

2009-12-27T20:00:00Z : Found it by sierra-mike
We found it during our beautiful walk with my wife's sister and her husband through the Ardgillan Park. We infected my sister in law and her husband with geocaching, so we did all the caches in this area. TFTC!

2009-10-18T19:00:00Z : Found it by mr-frog
TFTC easy find. Stamp stamp stamp. In. Christmas tree trinket & TB Out: Bouncy ball.

wpt.name: GC1D4R5
wpt.desc: Ardgillan III "The Yew Walk" by Windsockers, Traditional Cache (1.5/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Ardgillan III "The Yew Walk"
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Ardgillan is a very well preserved castle near Skerries to the North of Dublin, surrounded by beautiful gardens and set in a great landscape.
A visit to the castle is highly recommended.

The Yew Walk

One surviving feature still intact in the garden is the Yew Walk which lies to the south of the house and is seen as one approaches from the entrance at Blackhills. This was planted in 1800's during the lifetime of Marianne Taylor, wife of Rev. Henry Edward Taylor. It was the favourite walk of Captain Edward Taylour (1863 - 1938). Local folklore has it that a shadowy figure sometimes seen here is the ghost of a member of the Taylour family.

From the cache, you will have spectacular views over the grounds and on a clear day you can see the Mourne mountains in the distance.

Getting There

There are two ways to get to this cache: from the main car park at N 53 34.922 W 006 09.645,
or the pedestrain route at the "Ladies Stairs" at N 53 35.473 W 006 09.365.

If you want to visit this cache using public transport, the bus route to take from Dublin City centre is the No. 33 which will drop you off at the "Ladies Stairs" on the road between Balbriggan and Skerries, the pedestrian entrance to the Demesne via a bridge which spans the road and railway line. Alternatively, you can take the 41 from Dublin City Centre to Swords, and then take the 33A (which from Swords on follows the same route as the 33).

Note that access to the grounds is open from 10am to 5pm in the Wintertime, and 10am to 9pm in the summer (June, July and August).



The Windsockers
